questions.question_text: Which two components are essential parts of a Cisco ACI Virtual Machine Manager (VMM) domain policy configuration? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
VMM Main Components:
> Virtual Machine Manager Domain Profile (C)
> Credential
> Controller
> EPG Association (D)
> Attachable Entity Profile Association (AEP)
> VLAN Pool Association
That's correct, C and D.

choices.B: LB Mode: Destination IP Address and TCP/UDP Port
choices.D: LB Mode: Source IP Address and TCP/UDP Port
choices.C: LB Mode: Source and Destination MAC Address

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
CE.
Wrong comments here, unclear why. 2 part to setup LACP & LB algorithm.
LACP needs to be active, unclear why omitted here in discussion by someone, it is enhanced LAG policy, so part of question. Cannot be source IP (TEP is not changing), cannot be dst port - same for common services, cannot be dest IP - same destination VM. So fits source & dst mac.

Selected Answer: BE
It should be 
B and E..
We need to select a mode and this is LACP Active and we can select just one load balancing hash when we are creating a Port Channel Policy for VDS and since the vCenter has a lot of IPs inside it, the best choice it would be IP destination. Also, the source IP or MAC will be the same.

Selected Answer: BD
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/aci_virtual_edge/configuration/2-x/Cisco-ACI-Virtual-Edge-Configuration-Guide-202/Cisco-ACI-Virtual-Edge-Configuration-Guide-202_chapter_0100.html

Selected Answer: DE
i think it is D and E

Selected Answer: BD
BD,

Cisco Application Centric Infrastructure Virtual Edge, VXLAN mode traffic always uses the source IP address as the TEP IP address. To ensure proper load balancing, we recommend the algorithm Source and Destination TCP/UDP Port.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/aci_virtual_edge/configuration/2-x/Cisco-ACI-Virtual-Edge-Configuration-Guide-202/Cisco-ACI-Virtual-Edge-Configuration-Guide-202_chapter_0100.html

Selected Answer: AB
https://aci-lab.ciscolive.com/lab/pod10/acivmm/vmm-build

LACP Standby will give chance to the Leaf switches to initiate LACP BPDUs, Loadbalancing will be more variable to many destinations (More random flows).

Selected Answer: AB
This is a vSwitch policy and they want network switches to initiate LACP negotiations -> LACP Standby. Traffic is flowing from a limited number of VMs to the rest of the network -> LB Mode: Destination IP/Port. LB Mode can be different in the opposite direction!

comments.content:
This is the correct answer.

The configs are will be configured on the VDS and face back to the ACI Leaves.
https://aci-lab.ciscolive.com/lab/pod10/acivmm/vmm-build

discussion.content:
for me it is C and E based on this document:

https://community.cisco.com/t5/data-center-and-cloud-knowledge-base/vmm-integration-with-enhanced-lacp/ta-p/4522997

possibly CE
consider vmotion - The LAG group consists of two 10 Gigabit Ethernet links
Cisco ACI considers the frequent move of an IP address from one MAC address to the other and potentially between ports as a misconfiguration. Features such as rogue endpoint control may quarantine the endpoints and raise a fault.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/dcn/whitepapers/cisco-application-centric-infrastructure-design-guide.html

In my opinion, it must be D and E. 
Because usually source port is ephemeral port which changes all the time, as result deifferent hashes that put traffic across multiple links. 
Secondly LACP must be ACTIVE.

Selected Answer: BD
complicated but I agree

Selected Answer: BD
The answer is B and D.

Explanarion:

LACP Mode: LACP Standby - In LACP available only two modes - Active and Passive
LACP Mode: Active its standard LACP mode
LB Mode: Source and Destination MAC Address its a standard LACP balancing mode

And question says: Which two enhanced LAG policies meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

 LB Mode: Destination IP Address and TCP/UDP Port
LB Mode: Source IP Address and TCP/UDP Port

This two modes are LACP enhanced balancing modes

everyone forgets that we're configuring the "remote" side of connection (DVS on servers). ergo, it has to be LACP Passive (here called "standby"), and best-from-provided load balancing decision would be destination ip + tcp/udp

We dont know if its a "normal VDS" or an "AVE". So maybe they want to point to the AVE due to (https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/aci_virtual_edge/configuration/2-x/Cisco-ACI-Virtual-Edge-Configuration-Guide-202/Cisco-ACI-Virtual-Edge-Configuration-Guide-202_chapter_0100.html) 

so because "For Cisco ACI Virtual Edge VXLAN mode, it is mandatory to use a load-balancing algorithm having a UDP port. We recommend the algorithm Source and Destination TCP/UDP Port."

B and E should be correct

comments.content:
Cisco Application Centric Infrastructure Virtual Edge, VXLAN mode traffic always uses the source IP address as the TEP IP address. To ensure proper load balancing, we recommend the algorithm Source and Destination TCP/UDP Port.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/aci_virtual_edge/configuration/2-x/Cisco-ACI-Virtual-Edge-Configuration-Guide-202/Cisco-ACI-Virtual-Edge-Configuration-Guide-202_chapter_0100.html

discussion.content:
I think the anwsers are not complete. --> anwser should be LACP active / Src/Dst TCP/UDP

Possible anwsers: SRC/DST MAC, SRC/DST IP, SRC/DST TCP/UDP and LACP active or passive

I think C and E. 
I think that B and D are not correct as there are no such options

there is no mode of lacp standby in the APIC settings. LACP Mode: LACP Standby - is wrong!
In the Mode field, choose one of the following options appropriate to your setup:
 Static Channel - Mode On
 LACP Active
 LACP Passive
 MAC Pinning
 MAC Pinning-Physical-NIC-load

but the answer options clearly state - LACP Standby.

The server team requires the network switches to initiate the LACP negotiation as opposed to the servers. -->> A. LACP Mode: LACP Standby. I think that one part of the answer is A, because in ACI is configured LAG policy (within vSwitch Policy) that will be applied to VDS. And since network switches should initiate negotiation (LACP Active), on VDS should be configured LACP Pasive

comments.content: Correct, the vswitch policies apply to the VDS not the leaf switch thus LACP should be set to Passive and since this is a regular VDS I would use source and destination MAC.

discussion.content:
C, E as this is L2 traffic.
See https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/2-x/L2_config/b_Cisco_APIC_Layer_2_Configuration_Guide/b_Cisco_APIC_Layer_2_Configuration_Guide_chapter_0100.html to explain the different load balancing methods for L2 and L3 port channels.

B, E.
LACP mode: active
LB mode: dest ip and port

comments.content: E is required as Leaf need to initiate LACP. for 2nd option we have B or D. Not entirely sure what should be best answer, i will go with B and E.

discussion.content: The correct answers are B, D. Question ask distribute traffic across all available links

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer configures the Cisco ACI fabric for VMM integration with ESXi servers that are to be connected to the ACI leaves. The server team requires the network switches to initiate the LACP negotiation as opposed to the servers. The LAG group consists of two 10 Gigabit Ethernet links. The server learn also wants to evenly distribute traffic across all available links. Which two enhanced LAG policies meet these requirements? (Choose two.)
Which tenant is used when configuring in-band management IP addresses for Cisco APICs, leaf nodes, and spine nodes?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Management IP addresses = mgmt

Selected Answer: D
D

ACI fabric nodes have two options for management connectivity; out-of-band (OOB), which governs the dedicated physical management port on the back of the device, or in-band (INB), which is provisioned using a specific EPG/BD/VRF in the management tenant with a degree of configurable parameters.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/cloud-systems-management/application-policy-infrastructure-controller-apic/218028-troubleshoot-aci-management-and-core-ser.html
tenant mgmt is used for in- and out-of-band-mgmt

D is correct
guide config in-band using apic gui
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/4-x/basic-configuration/Cisco-APIC-Basic-Configuration-Guide-411/Cisco-APIC-Basic-Configuration-Guide-411_chapter_0100.html#task_730EB317BDE94145BAF91092F88B5257

B is correct. APIC connects to the Out of band (OOB) management net via dedicated mgmt0.
APIC also connect inband to the leafs via tenant infra vrf overlay-1

questions.question_text: What represents the unique identifier of an ACI object?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D

The ACI object model is represented in the Management Information Tree (MIT) that is an object oriented data base. Every branch represents a functional area, and every node is a managed object - has a CLASS and a globally unique Distinguished Name formed by a parent name and the relative name.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/policy-model-guide/b-Cisco-ACI-Policy-Model-Guide.html
D. Every MO in the system can be identified by a unique distinguished name (DN)

Correct, D 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/policy-model-guide/b-Cisco-ACI-Policy-Model-Guide.html

questions.question_text: Which type of profile needs to be created to deploy an access port policy group?

discussion.content: Option "A" is the correct answer however Option "D" (interface profile) is also required. So, in this case there should be multiple choice question.

Tricky Question! I'm not convinced AEP is correct as you can create an IPG without specifying an AEP! The question is to 'deploy' an IPG and I'd argue that's done by adding it to an interface selector, so my pick would be 'D'

Selected Answer: A
The answer should be A as the question expliclity ask for access POLICY GROUP and under this we must attached AEP else wont work. D would make sense if the question about Leaf Interface profile which is mapping out the interface selector to respective acess profiles.

Selected Answer: D
A leaf profile is the only possible solution. An attchable entity is no profile.

Selected Answer: D
AAEP is a profile while leaf interface is a Leaf Access Port policy group (tricky question cause it is asking about POLICY and not about PROFILE.
Fabric > Access Policies > Interfaces > Leaf Access Port > Create Leaf Access Port Policy Group 
You will need to select an option for Attached Entity Profile (AAEP) already created for this.

Selected Answer: D
AEP is a policy, not a profile. 
The interface profile needs to be created (Access Policies - Interfaces - Leaf Interfaces - Profile)

I also think its D because the question asked what is needed to deploy the policy group, it means he already have the policy group. AEP is part of the policy group, then you need the interface selector to deploy the policy group. If the question asked what is needed to create the policy group then it is AEP.

comments.content: after thinking it is A, from Access port policy we link attached entity profile

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
it is Leaf interface profile

Selected Answer: A
n AAEP - Go to Fabric > Access Policies > Global Policies > Attachable Access Entity Profile
This is the “glue” that connects our domains (i.e., Physical, VMM and External routed Domains) and our Vlan Pool
to Switches and Switch Interfaces.

https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/solutions/collateral/data-center-virtualization/application-centric-infrastructure/aci-guide-configuring-fabric-access-policies.pdf
Question seems to be related to a “deploy” action rather than to a create/configure one.I’d say D in this case
When setting the access port policy group, only AEP is required, no leaf interface is required. A is correct, D is wrong.
I think D https://www.networklife.net/images/sheets/Networklife_CheatSheet_ACI_02_Fabric_access_policies.pdf

The only Profile that should be assigned to Policy Group is attachable Entity Profile ,
I will go for answer A
Think it is D: The question is what type of profile needs to be created , Interface Selectors are required in the Profile , nothing in the Policy Groups talks about "Profiles"
I think D is correct because you can create an interface profile without AEEP
I think D is correct, because its either Attachable Access entity or Attached Entity profile, not Attachable entity profile.

comments.content: AEP and AAEP are the same thing, Cisco changed the terminology from a certain version.

A is correct, you dont need leaf interface profile to create an Access Policy Port Group

https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/solutions/collateral/data-center-virtualization/application-centric-infrastructure/aci-guide-configuring-fabric-access-policies.pdf
